EDITORIAL.
T is with great regret that the NEWS-LETTER

announces the resignation of its Editor-in-Chief, Samuel C. Chew, Jr., 1909. Mr. Chew
was elected to the Board in December, 1906, and was made Editorin-Chief last October. He has been active in his work for the paper, and
we shall feel his loss deeply. Mr. Chew is going to follow summer
courses at the Sorbonne this summer, and his resignation is caused
by extra work in preparation for his voyage, which begins on May
25th.

Z

HE loss of our Editor-in-Chief has caused several promotions in the
Board. Mr. Pedrick was elected to the office of Editor-in-Chief, and
Mr. Corner to Assistant Editor-in-Chief. Mr. Owens, who was
elected to the Board of Editors in January of this year, becomes
News Editor. There is now room on the staff for one or two Freshmen. It should be a matter of class spirit for 1911 to have at least
one representative on the paper. Get to work, Freshmen ! Think
of the honor!

T the last meeting of the Board of Editors it was decided to change
the policy of the Nnws--,T wrTgR. Already this year the paper has
followed two distinct courses, and we now find it necessary to change
again. At the beginning of the year, the paper was purely literary,
a style which failed to appeal to the majority of the student body.
V
Next we adopted the newspaper type, but found this impracti*
cable, because all of the news is about two weeks' old when it appears
*If*
in print. Consequently, we shall try to make the NEWS-LETTER
more like a magazine, having editorials, short stories, alumni and

university notes, and short accounts of the athletic and other college
activities. We invite criticism of the paper', and shall be glad to receive suggestions in regard
to the policy 0f the paper.

This table shows that Johns Hopkins is
wealthier per student than any other institution, excepting Leland Stanford, although it
stands, as respects the number of students,

twenty-second. In a complete list of colleges,
Hopkins would stand still farther down the
list in numbers, as such institutions as Valparaiso University, at Valparaiso, Ohio, with
its five thousand students and no endowment,
would be included.
Columbia is the richest of all, followed
closely by Harvard, Stanford, and Chicago.
It will be noted that the State universities are,
generally speaking, poorer than the private
foundations. It is interesting to notice how
the Johns Hopkins University's endowment,
which, in 1876, was the largest gift ever
made by one man to an American institution
of learning, has been eclipsed by the millions
of Stanford and Chicago.

THE JUNIOR BANQUET EXPENSES.
The matter of the expenses for the breakage
at the Junior banquet has, we are glad to say,
been arranged.
The Juniors will be called on for a dollar and
a quarter apiece and it seems that this sum is
enough to pay the entire bill.
It is to be hoped that no one will refuse to
pay this amount because of not having been
present, as it is evident, that in a matter like
this, each member of the two classes should
bear his share of the expense, whether he
approved of the action or not.

Dr. Carl R. Meloy, who is a bachelor of

THE NEWS-LETTER.

HIS CLOSEST CALL.
Captain Jim Marshall lived on a small farm
bordering on one of the largest tributaries of
the Chesapeake Bay. In the summer he made
his living by selling the products of his farm;
in the winter, autumn, and early spring,
however, he earned it by oystering.
He was a medium-sized man, about five
fee eight inches tall, and of a rather heavy
build. His features were very regular and
his expressive brown eyes were surmounted
by heavy gray brows. He had a heavy gray
moustache. To all his neighbors, "Captain
Jim," as he was commonly called, was known
to be good natured and jovial, but in the expression of his mouth and jaw there was an
unmistakable look of determination. Very
few people had ever seen this evinced, but
one of his neighbors, old man Simon Jones,
who had known him when a boy, once said:
"Jim's right good natured, but don't ye cross
him, 'cause if anything goes the way he don't
like it, he's as stubborn as that old Sally mule
of mine, browsing out there on the lawn."
It was the latter part of April, the day after
the oyster law was up. Captain Jim had had
an unusually successful season, had made a
great deal of money, and was preparing to
enjoy a few luxuries of life during the Summer. The temptation, however, was too
great. During the night a thick fog had
settled over the river, and, when Captain Jim
awoke the next morning, he found the dense
fog and a gentle breeze blowing from the
south. It was too much for him. He must
have, as he expressed it, "Another crack at
them oysters."
After eating a hasty breakfast, he went
down to the shore, where the night before he
had tied his little thirty-foot skiff, preparatory
to cleaning it up and hauling it out the next
day. He soon put things in order, hoisted
the sail, and started out for the oyster grounds.
He sat in the stern of the boat fairly beaming
with delight, holding the sheet rope with one
hand, and the tiller with the other, while between his teeth he tightly clasped the stem of
an old clay pipe. The very fact that he was
breaking the law seemed to delight him. In
the distance, he could distinctly hear the
noise of the paddle wheels of the old night
boat as she carefully picked her way out of

5

the river, sounding her deep whistles at
regular intervals,,about a minute apart; while
behind him he could hear everything just
waking up at home; the cocks crowing, the
neighing of the horses, the lowing of the
cows, and other sounds characteristic of no
other place except a farm.
Captain Jim soon rounded a small island,
some distance out in the river. He was now
nearing his destination and, after a half-hour's
sail he brought his boat up to the wind. Going
forward, he carefully dropped his anchor, and
lowered his sail. Great care had to be taken
not to make any noise, for there was an
oyster police boat out, looking for just such
poachers as Captain Jim.
Perhaps two hours had elapsed and he had
tonged about five bushels of oysters. In fact,
he had struck a gold mine in that respect, as
the bar upon which he was oystering had
never been known to anyone, and he, himself,
had only lately discovered it.
A fresh breeze now sprang up and the fog
lifted a little. To his dismay Captain Jim
saw the "Eliza Heyward," a large twomasted schooner and the fastest boat in the
police fleet, not more than a quarter of a mile
away, and bearing down upon him under full
sail. There was no doubt about it, he was in
a bad fix. At first, he thought he might
have escaped the notice of the keen-eyed
police officers, but, when a shot rang out and
a bullet clipped the water in front of him, he
became aware of the fact that he was mistaken.
Swiftly rushing forward, he hauled in his
anchor and hoisted his sail. Just then another
shot rang out and a bullet tore a hole in the
sail about two feet above his head. The situation was indeed becoming dangerous, but the
captain of the swift little skiff was not a man
to have fear and be taken without, at least,
making a fight for liberty. Calmly grasping
the tiller with his right hand, with an unusual
sparkle in his eyes, and with beads of mist
on his eyebrows and moustache, he pointed
his little skiff westward toward the mouth of
the river. At every puff of wind the little boat
seemed to respond and leap forward. On the
two boats went, the smaller one gaining little
by little. The wind now veered around to the
east, and with a mighty jibe, the big foresail,

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

the only sail on the boat, swung around, and
Captain Jim, with the "Eliza Heyward"
looking up in the distance like a great demon
and following close on his heels, headed with
a fair wind for the west side of the Chesapeake.
However, he had not the slightest intention
of crossing the bay. He steered straight in
the direction of Sharp's Island, where he
intended to pull up his center board and sail
across the flats, which, on account of her
draught, the pursuing boat could not cross.
Then, he was going to sail around on the lee
side of the island and beat back up the river.
This plan would have succeded, had not the
men on the police boat detected it and, when
he emerged on the other side of the island,
greeted him with a welcoming shot.
The chase was now renewed. This time
both boats had to beat up the river. At first
neither boat gained very much. Occasionally,
a shot from the "Heyward" informed Captain
Jim that he was not forgotten. He now began
taking shorter tacks which enabled him to
gain on the larger boat.
It so happened that at this stage of the race,
a boat, containing two young darkies, crossed
directly in front of the "Heyward." The police
officers, thinking that this was Captain Jim
started in pursuit and were, thus, thrown off
the track. Captain Jim now had little trouble
in finding his way home.
However, in later years when telling about
his various poaching expeditions and pursuits
by police boats, Captain Jim always declared
that, in escaping from the "Heyward," he
had his closest call.

iglYWNrra
• The host of pessimists that predicted dire
things for the Lacrosse team at the opening of
the season, and after the Navy game, have
changed for the most part into a bunch of
enthusiasts, who are already considering where
will be the best place to hang the championship banner. With four victories, one of
them in the champion series, the team is in fine
condition for the game with Stevens tomorrow.
Last Saturday's game showed what our team
is capable of. Lehigh was credited with
having a better team than last year's. If such
is the case, the 6 to 2 victory is all the more a
noteworthy one.
It is no exaggeration to say that the success
of the teams is in no small measure due to
Lowndes, at center. Since it became evident
that Gutman would be unable to play the
position which he filled so creditably last year,
the entire responsibility for the mid-field position devolved upon Lowndes, who until a
couple of months ago, never had a stick in his
hand. Now he plays a strong, hard, heady
game, not spectacular, perhaps, but consistant
and reliable.
Meanwhile the Freshmen are plugging on,
faithfully practicing,in the hope of duplicating
the defeat they administered to the top-heavy
Juniors. And the latter, with the second
game but a week off, are seemingly indifferent,
and have had only one or two practices at
the most.

STEVENS RECORD.
The game tomorrow between the Varsity
and Stevens Institute will undoubtedly be one
of the hardest of the season to win, for of all
the northern colleges Stevens has been showing
the best form. Her record in the first game
with Columbia is not very good, as the New
Yorkers were only defeated 2 to 0. In her
second game, however, a vast improvement
was shown. In this game the crack team of
the Crescent Athletic Club was defeated 4 to 2.
The game was played under bad weather conditions, but the stickwork and all around play
of the winners was of the highest order.
Goals were made in this game by Roberts (2),
Hamilton (1), and Armstrong (1).
Last Saturday Stevens defeated Harvard 6
to 2. Their forwards began with a rush that
scored two goals in the first five minutes play.
The defense was strong in this game. Roberts
and Cunningham each scored two goals, while
Smith and Brewer shot one each. Stevens'
lineup in this game was as follows:
Sturken, goal; Halm, point; Von Voightlander, cover-point; Erlenkotter, first defence;
Kennedy, second defence; Thayer, third defence ; Armstrong, center ; Roberts, third
attack; Smith, second attack; Brewer, first
attack; Hamilton, outhome ; and Cunningham, inhome.
Swarthmore is also up to the usual standard
this year, having defeated its Alumni and
being defeated by Mount Washington by a

fastest attack men. Hall at center puts up a

THE HOPK1NS—NAVY MEET,
Our meet with Navy, which will be held at
Annapolis tomorrow afternoon, promises to be
very close this year, as a number.of good men
will represent the Black and Blue in the different events.
The dash events will probably be the closest
contested of the meet. Our spint men, Bailey
and Stollenwerck, are fast, and are in good
condition now. While on the other hand,
Carey, who has returned to the Navy is one
of the best dash men of the State.
Of course, we will miss Breyer, who will be
away with the lacrosse team, but the distance
events will be well taken care of by Captain
Brenton and Griffith. Those who will probably be entered are as follows:
100, 220, and 440 yard dashes—Bailey,
Stollenwerck, and Stewart.
One half-mile arid mile runs—Griffith and
Brenton.
High and low hurdles—Stewart and Bridgman.
High jump—Burgan and Maynard.
Br o a d jump—Stewart, Treadway, and
Deming.
Shot put—Miller and Bryant.
Hammer throw—McGoffin and South.

Johns Hopkins Freshmen was defeated by the
Country School nine by 11 to 5. The defeat
was due mainly to the lack of practice of the
Freshmen, for Cooper pitched splendid ball,
and had he received good support would certainly have won his game.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"SIGNS OF SPRING-FEVER."
In the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER we
printed a poem on the "Signs of Spring,"
but by now we are sure that Spring has passed
and summer is here. The good old summer
time, when the sun beats down upon you as
you hurry along to your nine o'clock class,
and not even a breeze stirs to fan your heated
brow. Who can stay in laboratories for three
long hours looking at sections of chicks through
a microscope or standing beside a Bunser burner? It is really torture to have to spend
one's afternoons cooped up in "lab." when
the weather is as hot as it has been for the
past week.
We think that the laboratories ought to be
closed by the first of May or the fifteenth at
the very latest! We are only human, and it
is absolutely cruel to make us work in laboratory up to the very day before the final exams.
Oh, those final exams, only four weeks off!
How shall we ever be able to prepare for them,
if the temperature keeps as high as now?
And then there are the "Pop" concerts,

we shall feel his loss deeply. Mr. Chew is going to follow summer
courses at the Sorbonne this summer, and his resignation is caused
by extra work in preparation for his voyage, which begins on May
25th.

Z

HE loss of our Editor-in-Chief has caused several promotions in the
Board. Mr. Pedrick was elected to the office of Editor-in-Chief, and
Mr. Corner to Assistant Editor-in-Chief. Mr. Owens, who was
elected to the Board of Editors in January of this year, becomes
News Editor. There is now room on the staff for one or two Freshmen. It should be a matter of class spirit for 1911 to have at least
one representative on the paper. Get to work, Freshmen ! Think
of the honor!

the policy of the Nnws--,T wrTgR. Already this year the paper has
followed two distinct courses, and we now find it necessary to change
again. At the beginning of the year, the paper was purely literary,
a style which failed to appeal to the majority of the student body.

cable, because all of the news is about two weeks' old when it appears

This table shows that Johns Hopkins is
wealthier per student than any other institution, excepting Leland Stanford, although it
stands, as respects the number of students,

twenty-second. In a complete list of colleges,
Hopkins would stand still farther down the
list in numbers, as such institutions as Valparaiso University, at Valparaiso, Ohio, with
its five thousand students and no endowment,
would be included.
Columbia is the richest of all, followed
closely by Harvard, Stanford, and Chicago.
It will be noted that the State universities are,
generally speaking, poorer than the private
foundations. It is interesting to notice how
the Johns Hopkins University's endowment,
which, in 1876, was the largest gift ever
made by one man to an American institution
of learning, has been eclipsed by the millions
of Stanford and Chicago.

THE JUNIOR BANQUET EXPENSES.
The matter of the expenses for the breakage
at the Junior banquet has, we are glad to say,
been arranged.
The Juniors will be called on for a dollar and
a quarter apiece and it seems that this sum is
enough to pay the entire bill.
It is to be hoped that no one will refuse to
pay this amount because of not having been
present, as it is evident, that in a matter like
this, each member of the two classes should
bear his share of the expense, whether he
approved of the action or not.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

HIS CLOSEST CALL.
Captain Jim Marshall lived on a small farm
bordering on one of the largest tributaries of
the Chesapeake Bay. In the summer he made
his living by selling the products of his farm;
in the winter, autumn, and early spring,
however, he earned it by oystering.
He was a medium-sized man, about five
fee eight inches tall, and of a rather heavy
build. His features were very regular and
his expressive brown eyes were surmounted
by heavy gray brows. He had a heavy gray
moustache. To all his neighbors, "Captain
Jim," as he was commonly called, was known
to be good natured and jovial, but in the expression of his mouth and jaw there was an
unmistakable look of determination. Very
few people had ever seen this evinced, but
one of his neighbors, old man Simon Jones,
who had known him when a boy, once said:
"Jim's right good natured, but don't ye cross
him, 'cause if anything goes the way he don't
like it, he's as stubborn as that old Sally mule
of mine, browsing out there on the lawn."
It was the latter part of April, the day after
the oyster law was up. Captain Jim had had
an unusually successful season, had made a
great deal of money, and was preparing to
enjoy a few luxuries of life during the Summer. The temptation, however, was too
great. During the night a thick fog had
settled over the river, and, when Captain Jim
awoke the next morning, he found the dense
fog and a gentle breeze blowing from the
south. It was too much for him. He must
have, as he expressed it, "Another crack at
them oysters."
After eating a hasty breakfast, he went
down to the shore, where the night before he
had tied his little thirty-foot skiff, preparatory
to cleaning it up and hauling it out the next
day. He soon put things in order, hoisted
the sail, and started out for the oyster grounds.
He sat in the stern of the boat fairly beaming
with delight, holding the sheet rope with one
hand, and the tiller with the other, while between his teeth he tightly clasped the stem of
an old clay pipe. The very fact that he was
breaking the law seemed to delight him. In
the distance, he could distinctly hear the
noise of the paddle wheels of the old night
boat as she carefully picked her way out of

5

the river, sounding her deep whistles at
regular intervals,,about a minute apart; while
behind him he could hear everything just
waking up at home; the cocks crowing, the
neighing of the horses, the lowing of the
cows, and other sounds characteristic of no
other place except a farm.
Captain Jim soon rounded a small island,
some distance out in the river. He was now
nearing his destination and, after a half-hour's
sail he brought his boat up to the wind. Going
forward, he carefully dropped his anchor, and
lowered his sail. Great care had to be taken
not to make any noise, for there was an
oyster police boat out, looking for just such
poachers as Captain Jim.
Perhaps two hours had elapsed and he had
tonged about five bushels of oysters. In fact,
he had struck a gold mine in that respect, as
the bar upon which he was oystering had
never been known to anyone, and he, himself,
had only lately discovered it.
A fresh breeze now sprang up and the fog
lifted a little. To his dismay Captain Jim
saw the "Eliza Heyward," a large twomasted schooner and the fastest boat in the
police fleet, not more than a quarter of a mile
away, and bearing down upon him under full
sail. There was no doubt about it, he was in
a bad fix. At first, he thought he might
have escaped the notice of the keen-eyed
police officers, but, when a shot rang out and
a bullet clipped the water in front of him, he
became aware of the fact that he was mistaken.
Swiftly rushing forward, he hauled in his
anchor and hoisted his sail. Just then another
shot rang out and a bullet tore a hole in the
sail about two feet above his head. The situation was indeed becoming dangerous, but the
captain of the swift little skiff was not a man
to have fear and be taken without, at least,
making a fight for liberty. Calmly grasping
the tiller with his right hand, with an unusual
sparkle in his eyes, and with beads of mist
on his eyebrows and moustache, he pointed
his little skiff westward toward the mouth of
the river. At every puff of wind the little boat
seemed to respond and leap forward. On the
two boats went, the smaller one gaining little
by little. The wind now veered around to the
east, and with a mighty jibe, the big foresail,

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

the only sail on the boat, swung around, and
Captain Jim, with the "Eliza Heyward"
looking up in the distance like a great demon
and following close on his heels, headed with
a fair wind for the west side of the Chesapeake.
However, he had not the slightest intention
of crossing the bay. He steered straight in
the direction of Sharp's Island, where he
intended to pull up his center board and sail
across the flats, which, on account of her
draught, the pursuing boat could not cross.
Then, he was going to sail around on the lee
side of the island and beat back up the river.
This plan would have succeded, had not the
men on the police boat detected it and, when
he emerged on the other side of the island,
greeted him with a welcoming shot.
The chase was now renewed. This time
both boats had to beat up the river. At first
neither boat gained very much. Occasionally,
a shot from the "Heyward" informed Captain
Jim that he was not forgotten. He now began
taking shorter tacks which enabled him to
gain on the larger boat.
It so happened that at this stage of the race,
a boat, containing two young darkies, crossed
directly in front of the "Heyward." The police
officers, thinking that this was Captain Jim
started in pursuit and were, thus, thrown off
the track. Captain Jim now had little trouble
in finding his way home.
However, in later years when telling about
his various poaching expeditions and pursuits
by police boats, Captain Jim always declared
that, in escaping from the "Heyward," he
had his closest call.

iglYWNrra
• The host of pessimists that predicted dire
things for the Lacrosse team at the opening of
the season, and after the Navy game, have
changed for the most part into a bunch of
enthusiasts, who are already considering where
will be the best place to hang the championship banner. With four victories, one of
them in the champion series, the team is in fine
condition for the game with Stevens tomorrow.
Last Saturday's game showed what our team
is capable of. Lehigh was credited with
having a better team than last year's. If such
is the case, the 6 to 2 victory is all the more a
noteworthy one.
It is no exaggeration to say that the success
of the teams is in no small measure due to
Lowndes, at center. Since it became evident
that Gutman would be unable to play the
position which he filled so creditably last year,
the entire responsibility for the mid-field position devolved upon Lowndes, who until a
couple of months ago, never had a stick in his
hand. Now he plays a strong, hard, heady
game, not spectacular, perhaps, but consistant
and reliable.
Meanwhile the Freshmen are plugging on,
faithfully practicing,in the hope of duplicating
the defeat they administered to the top-heavy
Juniors. And the latter, with the second
game but a week off, are seemingly indifferent,
and have had only one or two practices at
the most.

STEVENS RECORD.
The game tomorrow between the Varsity
and Stevens Institute will undoubtedly be one
of the hardest of the season to win, for of all
the northern colleges Stevens has been showing
the best form. Her record in the first game
with Columbia is not very good, as the New
Yorkers were only defeated 2 to 0. In her
second game, however, a vast improvement
was shown. In this game the crack team of
the Crescent Athletic Club was defeated 4 to 2.
The game was played under bad weather conditions, but the stickwork and all around play
of the winners was of the highest order.
Goals were made in this game by Roberts (2),
Hamilton (1), and Armstrong (1).
Last Saturday Stevens defeated Harvard 6
to 2. Their forwards began with a rush that
scored two goals in the first five minutes play.
The defense was strong in this game. Roberts
and Cunningham each scored two goals, while
Smith and Brewer shot one each. Stevens'
lineup in this game was as follows:
Sturken, goal; Halm, point; Von Voightlander, cover-point; Erlenkotter, first defence;
Kennedy, second defence; Thayer, third defence ; Armstrong, center ; Roberts, third
attack; Smith, second attack; Brewer, first
attack; Hamilton, outhome ; and Cunningham, inhome.
Swarthmore is also up to the usual standard
this year, having defeated its Alumni and
being defeated by Mount Washington by a

fastest attack men. Hall at center puts up a

THE HOPK1NS—NAVY MEET,
Our meet with Navy, which will be held at
Annapolis tomorrow afternoon, promises to be
very close this year, as a number.of good men
will represent the Black and Blue in the different events.
The dash events will probably be the closest
contested of the meet. Our spint men, Bailey
and Stollenwerck, are fast, and are in good
condition now. While on the other hand,
Carey, who has returned to the Navy is one
of the best dash men of the State.
Of course, we will miss Breyer, who will be
away with the lacrosse team, but the distance
events will be well taken care of by Captain
Brenton and Griffith. Those who will probably be entered are as follows:
100, 220, and 440 yard dashes—Bailey,
Stollenwerck, and Stewart.
One half-mile arid mile runs—Griffith and
Brenton.
High and low hurdles—Stewart and Bridgman.
High jump—Burgan and Maynard.
Br o a d jump—Stewart, Treadway, and
Deming.
Shot put—Miller and Bryant.
Hammer throw—McGoffin and South.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"SIGNS OF SPRING-FEVER."
In the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER we
printed a poem on the "Signs of Spring,"
but by now we are sure that Spring has passed
and summer is here. The good old summer
time, when the sun beats down upon you as
you hurry along to your nine o'clock class,
and not even a breeze stirs to fan your heated
brow. Who can stay in laboratories for three
long hours looking at sections of chicks through
a microscope or standing beside a Bunser burner? It is really torture to have to spend
one's afternoons cooped up in "lab." when
the weather is as hot as it has been for the
past week.
We think that the laboratories ought to be
closed by the first of May or the fifteenth at
the very latest! We are only human, and it
is absolutely cruel to make us work in laboratory up to the very day before the final exams.
Oh, those final exams, only four weeks off!
How shall we ever be able to prepare for them,
if the temperature keeps as high as now?
And then there are the "Pop" concerts,
